summary: the 2009 swine-origin influenza virus (S-OIV) caused the first global influenza pandemic in recent decades. global concerns have been raised about an increasing threat of an influenza pandemic. current treatment strategies for influenza-A viruses, such as vaccines and drugs, have not provided broad and lasting protection. short defined or random peptides with a narrow length range are used to screen against monoclonal or polyclonal antibodies. the peptide library is generated by random digestion of the gene encoding the target viral protein. this is followed by a PCR-based reassembly step that results in fragments with controllable lengths. the full length HA gene of the pandemic 2009 A(H1N1) influenza virus was digested and re-assembled by PCR. the fragment library was ligated into the yeast display vector pCTCON-T (derived from the yeast surface display vector pCTCON-2 [23] shown in Fig. 1). the theoretical yield for cells expressing in-frame peptides is 1/3. vectors pCTCON-HA1 and pCTCON-HA2 created by inserting HA1 and HA2 genes between the Nhe I, BamH I sites of pCTCON-2 were used as positive controls in FCM detection. in step 3, the cell library was regions (residue 345) are indicated by dashed lines. the HA polypeptide is cleaved into two subunits linked by a disulfide bond, HA1 and HA2, to form the mature HA trimer. the majority of the HA1 subunit forms the viral membrane-distal globular head responsible for receptor binding, whereas the HA2 subunit together with the N- and C- termini of HA1 forms the membrane-proximal stem region that plays a major role in membrane fusion. 82 (82%) were picked randomly and sequenced, of which 82 contained in-frame inserts. the random library contained only 1/6 (16.7%) in-frame inserts efficiently. DNA fragments were digested and inserted between the Nhe I and BamH I sites of pCTCON-2 to create pCTCON-T. pCTCON-HA1 and pCTCON-HA2 were plasmids. the reassembled DNA samples were purified and modified to add 5′ A overhangs by an A-Tailing Kit (Takara) the backbone vector pCTCON-T was digested with Xcm I and purified with a Tiangen gel purification kit. the gene fragments and backbone vector were ligated at 16°C for 16 h and then electroporated into E. coli DH5 competent cells for propagation. cells were incubated with 1–2 g of fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) or phycoerythrin (PE) labeled secondary antibodies in 100 L at 4°C for 45 min. after washing two times with PBS, cells were resuspended in 1 mL of PBS and loaded onto a BD-FACS AriaIITM machine. the ratio of recombinant antigen expressed on the yeast surface (RAYS) was determined by dividing mean fluorescence intensity of peptide expressing yeast cells by the mean fluorescence intensity of the non-expressing (pCTCON-2) yeast cells. 1107 cells were harvested by centrifugation, incubated with goat antisera (1100 diluted in 100 L of PBS) and labeled with 1 g of FITC conjugated anti-goat secondary antibody. elastin-like polypeptide tag method (ELP) was used as the negative control. the wells were coated with 100 ng of peptides or Trx. but for human antisera, 10 ng of peptides or Trx control was used. the supernatants were used for determining the neutralization titers using a microneutralization assay with A/reassortants/NYMC X-179A/California/07/2009(H1N1) virus and MDCK cells according to standard procedures. cells were incubated at 35°C for 72 h, and the half maximal inhibitory concentration was determined. Restriction enzymes and DNA polymerases were purchased from New England Biolabs (Beverly, MA) or Takara (Dalian, China). oligonucleotides synthesized by Invitrogen or Takara. kits for DNA purification, gel recovery, plasmid miniprep and A-Tailing modification were obtained from Tiangen or Takara. two Xcm I restriction sites (CCANNNNN/NNNNTGG) were introduced between Nhe I and BamH I sites of pCTCON-2 to create pCTCON-T. random fragments with 3′ A tails were inserted between the two Xcm I sites by T-A ligation. the gene fragments and backbone vector were ligated at 16°C for 16 h. then electroporated into E. coli DH5 competent cells for propagation. plasmid library was then isolated and used to transform yeast EBY100 cells. library cells were incubated with 1–2 g of fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) or phycoerythrin (PE) labeled secondary antibodies in 100 L at 4°C for 45 min. cells were resuspended in 1 mL of PBS and loaded onto a BD-FACS AriaIITM machine (Shanghai, China) for sorting. yeast cells containing antigenic peptides were grown at 30°C for 24 h in SDCAA medium and induced at 20°C for 36 h in SGCAA medium. 1107 cells were harvested by centrifugation, incubated with goat antisera and labeled with 1 g of FITC conjugated anti-goat IgG secondary antibody. assays were developed by adding 100 L of 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) substrate solution and the reactions were stopped with 50 L of H2SO4 (1 M) each well was washed 4 times with PBST between steps. antiserum samples were incubated with 100 50% tissue culture infective dose (TCID50) of virus for 2 h at 35°C prior to adding MDCK cells. cells were incubated at 35°C for 72 h, and the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) was determined.
